hobby.message: That camera still your favorite weapon?
Political literature still keeping you up?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Heavier, yes. Everything's quieter than before, I suppose.
I was oiling an old typewriter at home, something I keep up with.
These curfews make it harder to focus, even on that.
Old hobbies have to adapt, like anything else now.
It's heavier. The streets feel strained, even inside.
I still try to service my typewriters—keeps the hands busy.
Hard not to notice the curfews creeping into your routines.
Used to write in a journal every day, now I do it less.
Sometimes you wonder if even hobbies are being watched.
You can feel it. Not just outside, but in the flat too.
I restore antique typewriters, bit unusual these days.
Usually, it's just a way to keep things orderly.
Recent checks and patrols made me put away my tools early.
I missed finishing a machine yesterday—had to leave it half-done.
Funny, how even an old carriage return can sound suspicious now.
Heavier, yes. It's not just the weather either, Alex.
I was midway into fixing an Adler typewriter when the patrol came by.
Collecting and restoring them has kept me grounded since before all this system business.
Yesterday, I nearly ruined a spring—hands were shaking when I heard boots in the hall.
Before, I’d write a bit after cleaning the keys. Now, I only jot notes sparingly.
Every visit or sound in the corridor—makes you second-guess even the click of typebars.
Feels odd, hiding a typewriter like it's contraband.
Definitely heavier—like we’re all holding our breath at once.
Most evenings I’d strip down a Remington or Adler for cleaning.
Restoring old typewriters is my escape—started long before retirement, before the BCI days.
Miss the rhythm of journaling—a real journal, not a data trace.
Last night, I froze mid-repair when Directorate came knocking on our floor.
Some neighbors simply disappeared after the new rules—now, I fix my machines in near-darkness.
Had to muffle a keystroke with cloth, just to be safe.
It’s strange, Alex, when caring for a typewriter begins to feel like defiance.
hobby_answer: Managed to get one, after a wait. Supply lines are slow lately.
Typewriters don't attract attention. Safer than you might think.
Just a quiet way to pass the time.
Curfews make it harder to get parts, though.
Best to keep hobbies simple these days.
Picked up a new ribbon, eventually. Deliveries are running late, with all the checks.
Still keep up the machines. They don't rely on network.
Hard finding carbons—used to trade with neighbors, but that's risky now.
Patrols have changed things. Noise travels more since the block emptied.
Even writing feels...monitored lately.
Found ribbon last week, though it cost double. Supply's unpredictable since the curfews.
Restored the old carriage—took patience. Quiet helps, at least.
I jot down daily notes. Years of habit—helps keep things clear.
With councils gone, fewer chats about old machines or repairs.
Strange, how even a noisy typewriter feels safer than speaking out loud.
Not much trust in digital records anymore.
I keep my best pages hidden.
Finally secured some ribbon—a friend from my old district had kept a spool.
The typewriter's more reliable than the power grid with these rolling outages, anyway.
Strange to see something mechanical feel almost rebellious now.
I write out thoughts, old policy quotes, recipes—keeps me grounded.
Used to trade ribbons at community meets. Those are finished with Directorate's crackdowns.
Patrols stopped by last week—left me jumpy, but they ignored the typewriter.
Guess the Directorate thinks paper’s harmless.
Even so, my journals are locked away now.
Yes, I found a ribbon, hidden in an envelope from my last Council desk.
I keep my Adler spotless. Typing feels like reclaiming a part of myself.
After Halden died, I started recording everything—dates, rumors, patrol patterns.
During the blackout, the machine was all I trusted.
Now that the Directorate silenced the forums, it feels like only paper remembers.
I miss sharing tips with neighbors—they all stay hidden since curfews.
Patrols get curious sometimes. I play the harmless old man. Still, I don’t type names.
Every sheet goes into my locked briefcase—some things aren’t meant for the system.
Strange, how an old ribbon feels like resistance in these times.
